column67: consequences: Rerun of failing tests without analyzing the failure
column68: consequences: Rerun of passing tests assuming hidden bugs
column69: consequences: Developer time gets wasted inspecting flaky failures
column70: consequences: Computing power is spent rerunning flaky tests
column71: consequences: Merging pull-requests is harder because this requires a passing test suite
column73: otherConsequences: otherConsequences1
column76: rootCause: Making asynchronous calls without waiting for the result properly (thread.sleep)
column77: rootCause: Race conditions, deadlocks or other concurrency related errors
column78: rootCause: Prior test did not cleanup properly after running (i)
column79: rootCause: Another test that should run before your test and set up the environment was not executed (successfully) (i)
column80: rootCause: Could not acquire resources because of a resource leak (i)
column83: rootCause: Relying on the system time (i)
column84: rootCause: Accessing values that were already deleted by the garbage collector or relying on the garbage collector to have already cleaned up
column85: rootCause: Using randomness without accounting for all possible values
column86: rootCause: Rounding errors when using floating-point operations
column87: rootCause: Assuming a specific order when iterating over unordered collections
column88: rootCause: Asserting a too restrictive range (i)
column89: rootCause: Single test takes too long (Test case timeout)
column90: rootCause: All tests together take too long (Test suite timeout)
column91: rootCause: Relying on a specific platform (e.g. 32/64 bit, Kernel version)
column92: rootCause: The test infrastructure fails to provide a proper environment (e.g. installing dependencies)
column93: rootCause: Reading values from uninitialized variables
column94: rootCause: Differences between compilers likeundefined behavior or compiler optimizations
column95: rootCause: Using random, non-seeded values for testing
column97: otherRootCauses: otherRootCause1
column101: mitigationStrategies: Rerun test in different environment
column105: mitigationStrategies: Automatically disable tests that show flaky behavior
column106: mitigationStrategies: Automatically file bug report / issue
column111: mitigationStrategies: Encourage developers to fix their flaky tests through incentives or penalties

column115: No broken window, In a nutshell, if you have a freshly painted building surrounded by other, well-maintained buildings, its facade will remain in a good state until the first window gets broken. column115: After you have driven the flaky tests out in the open, document every flaky test in your ticketing system. Flakiness related to concurrency can be caused by non-deterministic behaviour of the test, or the code under test. In some cases, there is a bug in the code. In others, the problem is that the code can produce different valid results, and the test accepts only one. This problem can be solved by making the test more robust, so that it accepts all valid results.

column73: Unclearness if your change actually causes problems or not (do test fail due to random issue or did you really introduce a problem). Thats why I often recheck my change again while the "next try" is running (which also is a waste of time if the change introduces no problems).

column115:
Machine readable infrastructure status of key infrastructure systems
Such status pages should have in general a machine readable interface so that other systems relying on it can query the status they depdend on as root cause for fails, flakynesses, etc.
E.g.: https://status.codecraft.bmw.cloud/ for Codecraft was for 6-9 month ok-ish maschine reabale until something changed screwing the curl access used to get the status.
Additional tools are not really needed; Android testing tools/frameworks/plattform should be more stable. I.e. 80% of flakyness is not related to the tests, but the environment they run in.

Test case execution visualization --> which test case failed how often with which error message on which device/environment.
automated dump (core dump, but also test controller dump) on exactly the point the test fails. (it is too often an assumption what failed due to too bad/loose/unrelated information about what failed) --> issue of bad written test cases.

Remark: I run and analyse more the test cases of others then writing own tests.

column115: A clean dashboard that visualises why a test failed. Currently we have to sift through pages and pages of log outputs and various other files on the CI server. A way to graph whether and which tests passed over the course of the previous weeks/months would be helpful in determining which tests are actually flaky. Currently we determine this using our own intuition.
